messages.text: <@U6788D83U> OK, I did it :smile:
oooh
PR?

I just meant I coded the tableau for the MIRK6. I look at the literature about adapted mesh for BVP, it is a mess (to sum up). I Dont know what you had in mind for the code. Your code reference “A Runge-Kutta Type Boundary Value ODE Solver with Defect Control” but there is no adaptation. Something really good is “Hale, Nicholas. “A Sixth-Order Extension to the MATLAB Package Bvp4c of J. Kierzenka and L. Shampine,” n.d., 17.” but it is “old” now.  Another issue for me is that this paper is about MIRK6 which has more filling obviously than MIRK4 for large scale problem. To me, I think the best around for midly stiff is “Cash, J. R., and F. Mazzia. “A New Mesh Selection Algorithm, Based on Conditioning, for Two-Point Boundary Value Codes.” _Journal of Computational and Applied Mathematics_ 184, no. 2 (December 15, 2005): 362–81. <https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cam.2005.01.016>.” But this mesh adaptation is tricky to say the least. TOM by Mazzia is also top class.

attachments.title: A new mesh selection algorithm, based on conditioning, for two-point boundary value codes
attachments.text: We present a hybrid mesh selection strategy for use in codes for the numerical solution of two-point boundary value problems. This new mesh strategy i…

messages.text: Hey, I've got a question about BVPs. Let's say I have a system of BVPs with four components, and I have one condition on the left boundary and three conditions on the right boundary. how do I express the `bc!` function in this case? Does the `residual` just take four components? Is there any special order they need to take on?

elements.text: Hey, I've got a question about BVPs. Let's say I have a system of BVPs with four components, and I have one condition on the left boundary and three conditions on the right boundary. how do I express the
function in this case? Does the
just take four components? Is there any special order they need to take on?

messages.text:
> Does the `residual` just take four components?
Yup
> Is there any special order they need to take on?
Nope, no order necessarily.

> So, I've never actually solved a differential equation before numerically, so I was going to start with this one, but then I remembered you telling me about some fancy julia package that can solve wacky ODEs. Could you give this one a shot?

elements.text: One of my supervisors came to me today with a funky differential equation and said

So, I've never actually solved a differential equation before numerically, so I was going to start with this one, but then I remembered you telling me about some fancy julia package that can solve wacky ODEs. Could you give this one a shot?

messages.text:
If I have a large N-compartment ODE model and I’m looking to parallelize the `ODEmodel(du,u,p,t)` function by `@distributed` on the for loop. Is this the ideal way to speed this up on a CPU with multiple nodes?

I thought maybe it would pay to give each node a chunk of the compartments, update the respective `u` components, broadcast it to the others and repeat. But this potentially seems bad unless I enforce a fixed time step which I think loses out on the utility of the adaptive step routines.

elements.text: If I have a large N-compartment ODE model and I’m looking to parallelize the

on the for loop. Is this the ideal way to speed this up on a CPU with multiple nodes?

I thought maybe it would pay to give each node a chunk of the compartments, update the respective
components, broadcast it to the others and repeat. But this potentially seems bad unless I enforce a fixed time step which I think loses out on the utility of the adaptive step routines.
